Report
LEFT ELBOW SERIES
 
HISTORY: Left elbow pain from a recent fall.
 
COMPARISON: None.
 
FINDINGS:  A three view exam demonstrates no acute fracture or
dislocation. The joint spaces appear unremarkable. There is soft tissue
swelling overlying the posterior ulna. There is diffuse osteopenia.
There is a tiny spur or old avulsion fracture from the olecranon.    
 
IMPRESSION: No acute bony abnormality.
 
   
 
 
 
LEFT FOREARM SERIES
 
HISTORY: Left arm pain from recent fall.
 
COMPARISON: None.
 
FINDINGS:  A two view exam demonstrates no acute fracture or
dislocation. The joint spaces demonstrate degenerative changes at the
wrist with radiocarpal narrowing, cystic change of the lunate and
advanced degenerative changes of the lunate. No soft tissue abnormality
is seen.    
 
IMPRESSION: Degenerative changes with no acute bony abnormality.
 
   
 
 
 
 
Images reviewed, interpreted, and dictated by Dr. Dale Absher.
Transcribed by Lee Garrett, R.T. (R).
 
I have personally viewed, interpreted and dictated the examination. I
have read and agree with the above final transcribed report.

Exam Date: 11/22/2020 20:58:00
Exam: 70450 - CT Head w/o Contrast
================================================================================

Department: ERS
Reason For Exam: Neuro deficit, right-sided weakness, expressive aphasia, on awakening this morning, severe headache last evening., stroke suspected

CT Head w/o Contrast

BRMC CT utilizes automated exposure control, adjustment of the mA and
/or kV according to patient size, and/or use of iterative
reconstruction technique.

Comparison: CT from 7/10/2019

Findings: There is encephalomalacia in the left temporal lobe. I think
this probably represents an old infarction. Some component of recent
infarction is not excluded. There is no mass, hemorrhage,
hydrocephalus or bony pathology. The mastoid air cells, middle ears
and portions of the paranasal sinuses included are clear.

Impression: Probably old infarction in the left temporal lobe. Some
component of recent infarction in this area is not excluded. MRI could
be used for further evaluation if clinically indicated.

D: Wilson, 11/23/2020 7:34 AM, NTS_Martinez


)

Exam: CT CHEST LOW DOSE


CT SCAN OF THE CHEST WITHOUT CONTRAST SCREENING PROTOCOL

COMPARISON: 12/19/2017

HISTORY: Current smoker with 40-pack-year smoking history..

PROCEDURE: Axial images were obtained from the lung apex to the mid abdomen by
computed tomography and a low-dose chest screening protocol.

CTDIvo is 1.23 mGy and DLP is 36.89 mGy-cm.

FINDINGS:

CHEST: There is no axillary adenopathy. There is no hilar or mediastinal
adenopathy. Heart size is normal. There is no pericardial or pleural effusion.
Limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. No suspicious infiltrate
or nodules identified. There are numerous calcifications consistent with old
granulomatous disease. There are mild emphysematous changes. There is trace
dependent atelectasis at the lung bases.

IMPRESSION: No acute process and no significant change.


Lung RADS Category 1: Continued low-dose chest CT recommended in one year.


Films reviewed , interpreted and dictated by Dr. Scalf.
Transcribed by Jeff Koch, PA-C.
